FeedItems.Title: Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:
NuGet.org will begin requiring two-factor authentication for accounts starting March 8th.
The post Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org appeared first on The NuGet Blog.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Fix org profile to show correct MFA status for site admins" (#9106) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "[Bug]: NuGet does not retry some HTTP timeouts" (#11779) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

dotnet 7.0 previews

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

NuGet's `HttpRetryHandler` has a `catch (OperationCancelledException) { throw; }` block in order to not retry when the input `cancellationToken` requests cancellation. However, `HttpClient` throws `OperationCancelledException` for some timeouts. This should be handled correctly with a `when (cancellationToken.IsCancellationRequested)` filter.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Xplat verfication: after merging to dev" (#9738) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: There're some unfinished tasks after merging the xplat verification feature branch to dev.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "add tests on cross verifying signed packages " (#9003) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Since we have some different code paths for different platforms for signing/verification, we should generate signed packages on all platforms(windows/Linux/Mac), and cross verify them.
The list of signed packages should be cross verified are:
1.Author signed.
2.Author signed & timestamped.
3.Repository signed.
4.Repository signed & timestamped.
5.Author signed , repository countersigned.
6.Author signed & timestamped, repository countersigned.
7.Author signed, repository countersigned & timestamped.
8.Author signed & timestamped, repository countersigned & timestamped.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Remove using specific version when downloading dotnet for testing" (#9712) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When running configure.ps1/runFuncTest.sh, the downloading of master branch failed as following:
```
dotnet-install: Downloading link: https://dotnetcli.azureedge.net/dotnet/Sdk/5.0.100-preview.7.20323.3/dotnet-sdk-5.0.100-preview.7.20323.3-win-x64.zip
dotnet-install: Cannot download: https://dotnetcli.azureedge.net/dotnet/Sdk/5.0.100-preview.7.20323.3/dotnet-sdk-5.0.100-preview.7.20323.3-win-x64.zip
dotnet-install: Downloading legacy link: https://dotnetcli.azureedge.net/dotnet/Sdk/5.0.100-preview.7.20323.3/dotnet-dev-win-x64.5.0.100-preview.7.20323.3.zip
dotnet-install: Cannot download: https://dotnetcli.azureedge.net/dotnet/Sdk/5.0.100-preview.7.20323.3/dotnet-dev-win-x64.5.0.100-preview.7.20323.3.zip
```
We need to figure out how often the failure is.
For now, we use specific version instead of latest version.
When it's confirmed that the latest version will be available in a stable status, we should remove the workaround.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Visual Studio Deep Link NuGet Package Install" (#11062) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Create custom solution picker for when Visual Studio starts from a URI" (#11181) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Update SPDX licenses to bb0099c" (#11765) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "PackageSourceMapping public constructor" (#11609) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet SDK

### The Elevator Pitch

We want to set the package source mapping dynamically on restore, not read them from a configuration file.
### Additional Context and Details

We don't have a static pattern for the package ids and we don't have the feeds in the configuration file, but we can set those when restoring. Making the existing constructor public would work.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "NuGet.Commands embedded copy of FileSystemGlobbing is now public" (#2345) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Because `preprocess` code is not available in RC2, the code that "internalizes" the copy of FileSystemGlobbing that NuGet.Commands embeds isn't in effect. As a result, the classes are public and conflict with the real FileSystemGlobbing. I've worked around it in CLI, but it should be fixed.

/cc @emgarten @yishaigalatzer @davidfowl

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org" (#61) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: We announced plans to require tFA on all accounts on NuGet.org. Details in the [blog post](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/requiring-two-factor-authentication-on-nuget-org/).
